FAKE PEP PILLS OR OTC LOCK-ALIKES
FDA has received numerous fnquiries about fake “pep pills,” imitation "speed"
| and other look-alike druas. These products usually contain caffeine or mixtures
| of cough-cold ingredients and are properly labeled and legal in the market. However,
they are made to look like controlled substances. The following may be used to
answer questions.

There has been a recent proliferation of non-prescription capsules and tablets
manufactured to mimic through their appearance various controlled, prescription
substances. Many of these products are a similar size,Cshepe and color, with similar

1, Markings, as amphetamine-type products such as Biphétanine T20, Ionamin-30, Dexedrine

; “and Fastin. The look-alikes usually contain a combination of legal over-the-counter

| drugs, including caffeine, pheny Ipropanolamine (an appetite suppressant and nasal

, decongestant) and ephedrine (a decongestant), or pseudoephedrine and caffeine, or

| ephedrine and caffeine, or just caffeine. These products are being distributed

| natiomide through ads in campus newspapers and the mails and are labeled ostensibly
in compliance with FDA's current labeling requirements for use as decongestants
and bronchodilators in the management of bronchial asthma and for use as stimulants
to aid mental alertness.

Persons purchasing large quantities may sell individual tablets without labeling,
as if they were strong, controlled stimulants.

FDA has received four reports of deaths associated with the use of these products.
Two females died after intentional overdoses, one after taking 50 tablets of caffeine.
Two males died from cerebral hemorrhage after use of these druas in combination with
other drugs and/or alcohol, but the cause of death has not been directly attributed

(1}to the look-alike drugs. -

The agency is encouraging and supporting state attempts to deal with this ™)
problem.

Six states have passed legislation banning the distribution of these
drugs and other states have such legislation under consideration. Excerpts
from two of the legislative proposals indicate the intent of the legislation:

"Prohibits the unlawful sate, manufacture, dispensing, or distribution
of counterfeit controlled substances. Also prohibits the possession of such
substances with the intent to set], manufacture, dispense, or distribute."

"It is unlawful for any person knowingly or {intentionally to agree,
consent, or in any manner offer to unlawfully sell, furnish, transport,
administer or give any controlled substance to any person or to arrange for
any of the above, and then to substitute a non-controlled substance in lieu of
the controlled substance bargained for."

The six states that have passed such legislation are: Delaware, Indiana,
Kansas, Arkansas, Maryland and South Dakota. Other states with Tegislation
under consideration are: Colorado, Connecticut, Florida, Louisiana, Minnesota, YY
New Hampshire, New Mexico (Resolution), Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon and Tennessee.

FDA recognizes the importance of the look-alike problem and will
pursue regulatory means to deal with violations of the Federal Food, Drug
and Cosmetic Act.
